Award.AwardTitle: Instrument Development: Development of Distance of Flight Mass Spectrometry Techniques for Chemical Measurement
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award, the Chemical Measurements and Imaging (CMI) Program in the Division of Chemistry is funding Drs. Steven Ray and Gary Hieftje at Indiana University to develop a group of chemical measurement techniques based on a new type of mass spectrometer, known as the distance-of-flight mass spectrometer (DOF-MS). The DOF-MS technique measures the distance each ion travels over a specified flight period to determine the ion mass-to-charge ratio (m/z). It offers many potential advantages, such as the determination of m/z for ions of very high mass, increased speed of measurement, improved dynamic range, adjustable and improved measurement resolution, and the subsequent collection of ions for follow-on analysis by other techniques. The applicability of a hybrid DOF-TOF MS instrument by the scientific community is expected to span across many fields, including bioanalytical chemistry, microbiology, the energy scieces and molecular biology. Drs. Ray and Hieftje are working with local mass spectrometry user facilities and Pacific Northwest National Laboratory (PNNL) to broaden the user basis and enhance the scientific impact of the new instrument being developed. Postdoctoral and graduate students involved in the research project experience valuable interdisciplinary training. Drs. Ray and Hieftje also are engaged in outreach activities by parterning with Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology, a local engineering-focused undergraduate institution, and a local K- 12 science education center to promote STEM student training and education.

The goal of this project is the development of a set of chemical measurement strategies based on distance-of-flight mass spectrometry (DOF-MS). In this project, a combination of DOF-MS and TOF-MS is developed as a means to realize the benefits of both approaches in a single instrument. This DOF/TOF strategy may have the potential to significantly improve chromatographic MS detection with extremely wide dynamic range, fast temporal response, and wide coverage. Specifically, Drs. Ray and Hieftje couple the spatial segregation of DOF-MS to a novel type of charge-sensitive ion detector array known as a focal-plane camera (FPC) to simultaneously measure the ion currents observed at every spatially discrete detector element, thus detecting the m/z and abundance for each desired mass-to-charge ratio (m/z) with very wide dynamic range and excellent temporal registry. In addition, Dr. Ray and his collaborators are developing a Zoom-TOF-MS approach that uses the ion focusing strategies of DOF-MS with a TOF-MS setup to improve the mass resolving power of the instrument while requiring only minor functional and architectural changes. Zoom-TOF-MS provides enhanced resolution as well as increased temporal resolution of the mass analyzer, and improves the signal-to-noise ratio (S/N). The supported research activities could potentially provide an enabling new tool for a broad segment of the scientific community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant revolved around the development of new technologies for mass spectrometry. Specifically, the development of a new mass spectrometer (known as the Distance-of-Flight Mass Spectrometer), new means of ion detection, and new mechanisms of ion formation. Distance-of-Flight Mass Spectrometry (DOFMS) has the advantage that it is able to separate  ions of different mass-to-charge ratio (m/z) as a function of space; when the distance an ion flies in a given time is measured it can be related to the ion m/z, and thus the ion mass.  This capability will make DOFMS a valuable tool to measure ions of large mass, or to separate and collect ions, both things that are difficult to accomplish currently.  

To make DOFMS feasible as a measurement technique, several aspects of its construction, design, operation, and optimization were developed through the support of this grant.  Several different ionizations sources were used with DOFMS, and experimental results used to understand the operation and requirements of the new approach.  

For example, new technologies are required to be detected at different locations as a means of determining their flight distance, and thus the ion m/z.  In this grant, a new approach to ion detection based on semiconductor integrated circuitry was explored.  This specialized semiconductor chip contains an array of extremely sensitive amplifier circuits, each attached to a small ion collection surface.  By measuring the amplifier output from each individual circuit (over 1700 in all), the flight distance of each of the ions sampled by the DOFMS could be measured simultaneously and for every ion in the m/z-range observed. This new approach, often termed an ?ion camera? was shown through this grant to have significant advantages over other current approaches.  In addition, this grant supported development of a much simpler and inexpensive alternative that could be used for a single, or few, ion collector elements.  This experimental approach used commercial off-the-shelf components to create a smaller, workable system and demonstrated its utility with the DOFMS.  The eventual goal of such a simple ion detector will be as an ion collection surface.  Most mass spectrometry analyses are destructive, meaning that once an ion is created and analyzed by the instrument, it is lost.  However, specialized approached known as soft-landing mass spectrometry allows for the ions to be analyzed and then collected on a secondary surface, to be saved for later use once removed from the vacuum of the instrument.

In order to observe a molecule by mass spectrometry, the molecule must first be charged to become an ion.  For this reason, the formation of the ion is a critical aspect of any mass spectrometry technology, since the ionization approach really forms the bridge between the sample and observed results.  In this grant, a new approach to ion formation was invented, which was termed microwave-assisted electrospray ionization. The hypothesis of this experiment was that highly-focused microwave fields would be able to interact with the aerosol of liquid droplets formed by a typical electrospray ionization approach. In doing so, these fields would heat the liquid and ions by dielectric heating, to create more abundant and various ions to be analyzed by the DOFMS.  Experimental results obtained through this grant proved this to be true, and showed the approach to be very efficient in the formation of negative ions in particular.  These experiments also demonstrated that this approach could be used to create small microwave microreactor systems especially for mass spectrometry by electrospray ionization.  Several experiments showed the viability of using this new ionization approach to greatly enhance and speed-up chemical and biochemical reactions for study by mass spectrometry.

Overall, this grant supported development of a new mass spectrometer (DOFMS), new means of ion detection (an ion camera), and new approach to ion formation (microwave-assisted electrospray ionization).
